sen.j: 天岩戸（あまのいわと）とは、日本神話に登場する岩で出来た洞窟である。
sen.e: The term, "Ama no iwato" refers to a rock cave that appears in Japanese mythology.
The term, "Ama no iwato" refers to a rock cave that appears in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: 全角半角文字の修正しました。
sen.e: The term, "Ama no iwato" refers to a rock cave that appears in Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 天戸（あまと）、天岩屋（あまのいわや）、天岩屋戸（あまのいわやと）とも言い、「岩」は「石」と書く場合もある。
sen.e: It is also referred to as "Amato," "Ama no iwaya," and "Ama no iwayato," and often written in kanji (Chinese characters) '石 (meaning stone),' instead of '岩 (meaning rock)."
It is also referred to as "Amato," "Ama no iwaya," and "Ama no iwayato," and often written in kanji (Chinese characters) '石' (meaning stone), instead of '岩' (meaning rock).
sen.cmt: の位置の訂正をしました。
sen.e: It is also referred to as "Amato," "Ama no iwaya," and "Ama no iwayato," and often written in kanji (Chinese characters) '石' (meaning stone), instead of '岩' (meaning rock).

sen.j: 太陽神である天照大神が隠れ、世界が真っ暗になってしまった岩戸隠れの伝説の舞台である。
sen.e: It was the place of Iwato-gakure legend that Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, hid herself in the heavenly rock cave, plunging the world into complete darkness.
It was the place of Iwato-gakure legend that Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, hid herself in the heavenly rock cave, plunging the world into complete darkness.
It was the place of Iwato-gakure legend that Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess, hid herself in the heavenly rock cave, plunging the world into complete darkness.

sen.j: 神話での記述
sen.e: Description in the mythology
Description in the mythology
Description in the mythology

sen.j: 古事記
sen.e: Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters)
Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters)
Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters)

sen.j: 誓約によって身の潔白を証明したスサノオは、そのまま高天原に居座った。
sen.e: Proving his innocence by ukehi (a divination), Susano (capricious younger brother of Amaterasu Omikami) sill stayed in Takamagahara (plain of high heaven).
sen.cmt: Susano (capricious younger brother of Amaterasu Omikami)を補足しました。
sen.e: Proving his innocence by ukehi (a divination), Susano (capricious younger brother of Amaterasu Omikami) sill stayed in Takamagahara (plain of high heaven).
Proving his innocence by ukehi (a divination), Susano (capricious younger brother of Amaterasu Omikami) sill stayed in Takamagahara (plain of high heaven).

sen.j: そして、田の畔を壊して溝を埋めたり、御殿に糞を撒き散らしたりの乱暴を働いた。
sen.e: He played havoc with Takamagahara; for example, he broke through the berms of rice paddies, filled in the irrigation ditches, and besmirched with excrement the palace.
He played havoc with Takamagahara; for example, he broke through the berms of rice paddies, filled in the irrigation ditches, and besmirched with excrement the palace.
He played havoc with Takamagahara; for example, he broke through the berms of rice paddies, filled in the irrigation ditches, and besmirched with excrement the palace.

sen.j: 他の神は天照大神に苦情を言うが、アマテラスは「考えがあってのことなのだ」とスサノオをかばった。
sen.e: The deities in Takamagahara complained about his rude conducts to Amaterasu, but she screened him from blame at first, saying, "He did so under some ideas."
The deities in Takamagahara complained about his rude conducts to Amaterasu, but she screened him from blame at first, saying, "He did so under some ideas."
The deities in Takamagahara complained about his rude conducts to Amaterasu, but she screened him from blame at first, saying, "He did so under some ideas."

sen.j: しかし、アマテラスが機屋で神に奉げる衣を織っていた時、スサノオは機屋の屋根に穴を開けて、そこから皮を剥いだ馬を落とし入れ、一人の天の服織女が驚いて梭（ひ）で陰部を刺して死んでしまった。
sen.e: These offenses she forgave, but he then broke a hole in the roof of her weaving hall when she was weaving clothes for deity, and cast in a dead horse that he had flayed backward, at whose sight a woman weaving the heavenly garments was so frightened that she fatally punctured her private part with her shuttle.

But he made a hole in the roof of weaving hall and cast a dead horse stripped off the skin into the hall where Amaterasu was weaving clothes for deity, when a weaving girl was so frightened, and dead by being stabbed in the genitals with her shuttle.
sen.cmt: 日本語にない所を削除して書き直しました。
sen.e: But he made a hole in the roof of weaving hall and cast a dead horse stripped off the skin into the hall where Amaterasu was weaving clothes for deity, when a weaving girl was so frightened, and dead by being stabbed in the genitals with her shuttle.

sen.j: ここにきてアマテラスはスサノオの行動に怒り、天岩戸に引き篭ってしまった。
sen.e: At last, his rude conducts infuriated Amaterasu and secluded herself in the Ama no iwato.
At last, his rude conducts infuriated Amaterasu and secluded herself in the Ama no iwato.
At last, his rude conducts infuriated Amaterasu and secluded herself in the Ama no iwato.

sen.j: 高天原も葦原中国も闇となり、様々な禍（まが）が発生した。
sen.e: Darkness descended upon Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (another world for the country or the location of Japan), and with her withdrawal every evil deity began to make a disturbance and every suffering happened all over the world covered with dead darkness.
Darkness descended upon Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (another world for the country or the location of Japan), and various kinds of maga (evil) occurred.
Darkness descended upon Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (another world for the country or the location of Japan), and various kinds of maga (evil) occurred.

sen.j: そこで、八百万の神が天の安河の川原に集まり、どうすれば良いか相談をした。
sen.e: Thereupon, yaoyorozu no kami (eight million gods) assembled at the river side of the Ame no Yasu-kawa River (the tranquil river of Heaven), and consulted what to do.
Thereupon, yaoyorozu no kami (eight million gods) assembled at the river side of the Ame no Yasu-kawa River (the tranquil river of Heaven), and consulted what to do.
Thereupon, yaoyorozu no kami (eight million gods) assembled at the river side of the Ame no Yasu-kawa River (the tranquil river of Heaven), and consulted what to do.

sen.j: オモイカネの案により、様々な儀式を行った。
sen.e: The various measures for revival of the sun goddess were planned by Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent).
The various measures for revival of the sun goddess were planned by Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent).
The various measures for revival of the sun goddess were planned by Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent).

sen.j: 常世の長鳴鳥（ニワトリ）を集めて鳴かせた。
sen.e: At first, the gods gathered chickens of Tokoyo no naganakidori (a long-singing chicken of eternal world that tells the end of the night, the daybreak), and made them crow each other.
At first, the gods gathered chickens of Tokoyo no naganakidori (a long-singing chicken of eternal world that tells the end of the night, the daybreak), and made them crow each other.
At first, the gods gathered chickens of Tokoyo no naganakidori (a long-singing chicken of eternal world that tells the end of the night, the daybreak), and made them crow each other.

sen.j: 天の安河の川上にある堅い岩を取り、鉱山の鉄を採り、鍛冶師の天津麻羅を探し、イシコリドメに命じて八咫鏡（やたのかがみ）を作らせた。
sen.e: Next, they took the hard rocks from the upper Ame no Yasu-kawa River, extracted the iron from a metal-mountain, searched for a blacksmith, Amatsumara, and ordered Ishikoridome to make Yata no Kagami (the eight-span mirror, one of the Imperial regalia).

Next, they took the hard rocks from the upper Ame no Yasu-kawa River, extracted the iron from a metal-mountain, searched for a blacksmith, Amatsumara, and ordered Ishikoridome to make Yata no Kagami (the eight-span mirror, one of the Imperial regalia).

Next, they took the hard rocks from the upper Ame no Yasu-kawa River, extracted the iron from a metal-mountain, searched for a blacksmith, Amatsumara, and ordered Ishikoridome to make Yata no Kagami (the eight-span mirror, one of the Imperial regalia).

sen.j: 玉祖命に命じて八尺の勾玉の五百箇のみすまるの珠（八尺瓊勾玉・やさかにのまがたま）を作らせた、アメノコヤネとフトダマを呼び、シカの肩の骨を抜き取り、ははかの木を取って占い（太占）をさせた。
sen.e: They ordered Tamanooya no Mikoto to make 'Yasaka no Magatama' (comma-shaped jewels), and then make 'Ihotsu no Misumaru no Tama' (a long string made of many comma shaped jewels) (also called Yasakani no Magatama), summoning Amenokoyane and Futodama to make them pull the shoulder-blade of a stag, take cherry-bark, and perform divination.
sen.cmt: 五百箇（いほつ）→五百個で数の多いのをいい、そういうたくさんの玉を統べ貫いたものがミスマルである。古事記注釈第二巻、西郷信綱、ちくま文芸文庫→(a long string made of many comma shaped jewels)を補足しました
sen.e: They ordered Tamanooya no Mikoto to make 'Yasaka no Magatama' (comma-shaped jewels), and then make 'Ihotsu no Misumaru no Tama' (a long string made of many comma shaped jewels) (also called Yasakani no Magatama), summoning Amenokoyane and Futodama to make them pull the shoulder-blade of a stag, take cherry-bark, and perform divination.

They ordered Tamanooya no Mikoto to make 'Yasaka no Magatama' (comma-shaped jewels), and then make 'Ihotsu no Misumaru no Tama' (a long string made of many comma shaped jewels) (also called Yasakani no Magatama), summoning Amenokoyane and Futodama to make them pull the shoulder-blade of a stag, take cherry-bark, and perform divination.

sen.j: 賢木（さかき）を根ごと掘り起こし、枝に八尺瓊勾玉と八咫鏡と布帛をかけ、フトダマが御幣として奉げ持った。
sen.e: They also dag Sakaki (cleyera japonica) from its root, on whose branches Yasaka no Magatama, Yata no Kagami, and fuhaku (cotton, silk, textile fabrics) were hung, and Futodama held it as a gohei (wooden wands, decorated with two Shide (zigzag paper streamers)).

They also dag Sakaki (cleyera japonica) from its root, on whose branches Yasaka no Magatama, Yata no Kagami, and fuhaku (cotton, silk, textile fabrics) were hung, and Futodama held it as a gohei (wooden wands, decorated with two Shide [zigzag paper streamers]).

They also dag Sakaki (cleyera japonica) from its root, on whose branches Yasaka no Magatama, Yata no Kagami, and fuhaku (cotton, silk, textile fabrics) were hung, and Futodama held it as a gohei (wooden wands, decorated with two Shide [zigzag paper streamers]).

sen.j: アメノコヤネが祝詞（のりと）を唱え、アメノタヂカラオが岩戸の脇に隠れて立った。
sen.e: Amenokoyane recited Norito (Shinto prayer), and Ameno Tajikarao stood hidden beside the entrance of the cave of heaven blocked with a huge rock.
Amenokoyane recited Norito (Shinto prayer), and Ameno Tajikarao stood hidden beside the entrance of the cave of heaven blocked with a huge rock.
Amenokoyane recited Norito (Shinto prayer), and Ameno Tajikarao stood hidden beside the entrance of the cave of heaven blocked with a huge rock.

sen.j: アメノウズメが岩戸の前に桶を伏せて踏み鳴らし、神憑りをして、胸をさらけ出し、裳の紐を陰部までおし下げて踊った。
sen.e: Amenouzume began a thunderous dance on an overturned tub, and divinely possessed, she exposed her breasts and lowered her skirt string to her genitals.
Amenouzume began a thunderous dance on an overturned tub, and divinely possessed, she exposed her breasts and lowered her skirt string to her genitals.
Amenouzume began a thunderous dance on an overturned tub, and divinely possessed, she exposed her breasts and lowered her skirt string to her genitals.

sen.j: すると、高天原が鳴り轟くように八百万の神が一斉に笑った。
sen.e: Her dance provoked uproarious laughter from all the other gods to the extent making Takamagahara ring.
Her dance provoked uproarious laughter from all the other gods to the extent making Takamagahara ring.
Her dance provoked uproarious laughter from all the other gods to the extent making Takamagahara ring.

sen.j: この声を聴いたアマテラスは、何事だろうと天岩戸の扉を少し開け、「自分が岩戸に篭って闇になっているというのに、なぜアメノウズメは楽しそうに舞い、八百万の神は笑っているのか」と問うた。
sen.e: Hearing that laughter, Amaterasu wondered what all the racket could be, opened the door of her cave a little, and asked why Amenouzume merrily danced and the yaoyorozu no kami were laughing notwithstanding the deep darkness in which her retirement resulted.

Hearing that laughter, Amaterasu wondered what all the racket could be, opened the door of her cave a little, and asked why Amenouzume merrily danced and the yaoyorozu no kami were laughing notwithstanding the deep darkness in which her retirement resulted.

Hearing that laughter, Amaterasu wondered what all the racket could be, opened the door of her cave a little, and asked why Amenouzume merrily danced and the yaoyorozu no kami were laughing notwithstanding the deep darkness in which her retirement resulted.

sen.j: アメノウズメが「貴方様より貴い神が表れたので、それを喜んでいるのです」と言うと、アメノコヤネとフトダマがアマテラスの前に鏡を差し出した。
sen.e: Amenouzume replied that they were congratulating on the appearance of the new deity more precious than her, and the great mirror was shown to Amaterasu by Amenokoyane and Futodama.
Amenouzume replied that they were congratulating on the appearance of the new deity more precious than her, and the great mirror was shown to Amaterasu by Amenokoyane and Futodama.
Amenouzume replied that they were congratulating on the appearance of the new deity more precious than her, and the great mirror was shown to Amaterasu by Amenokoyane and Futodama.

sen.j: 鏡に写る自分の姿がその貴い神だと思ったアマテラスが、その姿をもっと良く見ようと岩戸をさらに開けたとき、隠れていたアメノタヂカラオがその手を取って岩戸の外へ引きずり出した。
sen.e: Just when Amaterasu opened the door further in order to see the reflection on the mirror, which she thought to be that greater god, Ameno Tajikarao, who was standing hidden, grasped her hand and pulled her out.

Just when Amaterasu opened the door further in order to see the reflection on the mirror, which she thought to be that greater god, Ameno Tajikarao, who was standing hidden, grasped her hand and pulled her out.

Just when Amaterasu opened the door further in order to see the reflection on the mirror, which she thought to be that greater god, Ameno Tajikarao, who was standing hidden, grasped her hand and pulled her out.

sen.j: すぐにフトダマが注連縄を岩戸の入口に張り、「もうこれより中に入らないで下さい」と言った。
sen.e: Futodama immediately pulled shimenawa (a sacred rice-straw rope) taut in front of the door of the cave, and told her not to step inside any more.
Futodama immediately pulled shimenawa (a sacred rice-straw rope) taut in front of the door of the cave, and told her not to step inside any more.
Futodama immediately pulled shimenawa (a sacred rice-straw rope) taut in front of the door of the cave, and told her not to step inside any more.

sen.j: こうしてアマテラスが岩戸の外に出てくると、高天原も葦原中国も明るくなった。
sen.e: With Amaterasu coming forth, light returned to Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni.
With Amaterasu coming forth, light returned to Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni.
With Amaterasu coming forth, light returned to Takamagahara and Ashihara no Nakatsukuni.

sen.j: 八百万の神は相談し、スサノオに罪を償うためのたくさんの品物を科し、髭と手足の爪を切って高天原から追放した。
sen.e: Yaoyorozu no kami took counsel together, and Susano was made to submit vast quantities of goods in atonement, his hair was cut and his fingernails and toenails pulled off, and he was banished from Takamagahara.

Yaoyorozu no kami took counsel together, and Susano was made to submit vast quantities of goods in atonement, his hair was cut and his fingernails and toenails pulled off, and he was banished from Takamagahara.

Yaoyorozu no kami took counsel together, and Susano was made to submit vast quantities of goods in atonement, his hair was cut and his fingernails and toenails pulled off, and he was banished from Takamagahara.

sen.j: 日本書紀
sen.e: Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)
Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)
Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)

sen.j: 日本書紀でも大きな話の流れは同じであるが、細部に若干の違いがある。
sen.e: Although the mainstream of the myth concerning Ama no Iwato is almost the same between Kojiki and Nihonshoki, there are a few differences in detail between them.
Although the mainstream of the myth concerning Ama no Iwato is almost the same between Kojiki and Nihonshoki, there are a few differences in detail between them.
Although the mainstream of the myth concerning Ama no Iwato is almost the same between Kojiki and Nihonshoki, there are a few differences in detail between them.

sen.j: 本文では、スサノオが機屋に馬を投げた際、アマテラス自身が驚いて梭で傷ついたとある。
sen.e: The text of Nihonshoki describes that when Susano cast a dead horse into the weaving hall, it was Amaterasu who was so frightened that injured herself with a shuttle.
The text of Nihonshoki describes that when Susano cast a dead horse into the weaving hall, it was Amaterasu who was so frightened that injured herself with a shuttle.
The text of Nihonshoki describes that when Susano cast a dead horse into the weaving hall, it was Amaterasu who was so frightened that injured herself with a shuttle.

sen.j: 第一の一書では、稚日女尊（ワカヒルメ）が梭で傷ついて死んだとなっている。
sen.e: The first arufumi (alternative variants frequently supplementing main text of Nihonshoki) says that it was Wakahirume who hurt herself with a shuttle to die.
sen.cmt: 一書→あるふみ→ (alternative variants frequently supplementing main text of Nihonshoki) を補足しました
sen.e: The first arufumi (alternative variants frequently supplementing main text of Nihonshoki) says that it was Wakahirume who hurt herself with a shuttle to die.
The first arufumi (alternative variants frequently supplementing main text of Nihonshoki) says that it was Wakahirume who hurt herself with a shuttle to die.

sen.j: ワカヒルメはオオヒルメすなわちアマテラスの分身であり、スサノオの行為によってアマテラスが死んだというのが元々の伝承ではないかと考えられる。
sen.e: The original transmission is thought to have suggested that Wakahirume should be Ohirume, other self of Amaterasu, and the reckless demeanor of Susano should cause the death of Amatersu.
The original transmission is thought to have suggested that Wakahirume should be Ohirume, other self of Amaterasu, and the reckless demeanor of Susano should cause the death of Amatersu.
The original transmission is thought to have suggested that Wakahirume should be Ohirume, other self of Amaterasu, and the reckless demeanor of Susano should cause the death of Amatersu.

sen.j: 第二の一書では、アマテラスが怒って岩屋に隠れたのは、スサノオが神殿に糞をし、アマテラスが気付かずにそれに座ってしまったためとしている。
sen.e: The second arufumi describes that the reason Amaterasu was enraged at Susano's rudeness, and hid herself in the cave of heaven was that Susano voided excrement in her palace, on which she sat carelessly.

The second arufumi describes that the reason Amaterasu was enraged at Susano's rudeness, and hid herself in the cave of heaven was that Susano voided excrement in her palace, on which she sat carelessly.
sen.cmt: 全角文字の訂正をしました。
sen.e: The second arufumi describes that the reason Amaterasu was enraged at Susano's rudeness, and hid herself in the cave of heaven was that Susano voided excrement in her palace, on which she sat carelessly.

sen.j: アマテラスが天岩戸に隠れて世の中が闇になるという話は、日食を表したものだという解釈と、冬至を過ぎて太陽が弱まった力を取り戻すということを象徴したものとする見方がある。
sen.e: There are some interpretations about the mythical story which tells that Amaterasu hid herself in the rock cave of heaven and the darkness fell on the world; one is that the story represents solar eclipses, and another is that it is symbolic of the sun reviving its weak power after the winter solstice.

There are some interpretations about the mythical story which tells that Amaterasu hid herself in the rock cave of heaven and the darkness fell on the world; one is that the story represents solar eclipses, and another is that it is symbolic of the sun reviving its weak power after the winter solstice.
sen.cmt: 全角文字の訂正をしました。
sen.e: There are some interpretations about the mythical story which tells that Amaterasu hid herself in the rock cave of heaven and the darkness fell on the world; one is that the story represents solar eclipses, and another is that it is symbolic of the sun reviving its weak power after the winter solstice.

sen.j: 日食神話、冬至神話とも世界各地に見られる（→死と再生の神）。
sen.e: There can be seen eclipse mythologies and winter solstitial mythologies in various parts of the world (=>death and regeneration god).
sen.cmt: MyPageの用語集ではsolstitialが（スペルミスでは）solstitia になっておりました。
sen.e: There can be seen eclipse mythologies and winter solstitial mythologies in various parts of the world (=>death and regeneration god).
There can be seen eclipse mythologies and winter solstitial mythologies in various parts of the world (=>death and regeneration god).

sen.j: スサノオの乱暴は、その全てが農耕に関連するものであり、暴風雨の災害を表したものだともされる。
sen.e: The ravages that Susano had done in Takamagahara were all concerned about the agriculture; thus they are said to have represented havoc of heavy storm.
The ravages that Susano had done in Takamagahara were all concerned about the agriculture; thus they are said to have represented havoc of heavy storm.
The ravages that Susano had done in Takamagahara were all concerned about the agriculture; thus they are said to have represented havoc of heavy storm.

sen.j: 大祓詞では、このスサノオの行いを総称して「天つ罪・国つ罪」としている。
sen.e: These Susano's conducts are generically called 'amatsu-tsumi (heavenly sin) and kunitsu-tsumi (earthly sin) in the Oharae no kotoba (the great purification).
sen.cmt: 国つ罪→earthly sin と訳出しました
sen.e: These Susano's conducts are generically called 'amatsu-tsumi (heavenly sin) and kunitsu-tsumi (earthly sin) in the Oharae no kotoba (the great purification).
These Susano's conducts are generically called 'amatsu-tsumi (heavenly sin) and kunitsu-tsumi (earthly sin) in the Oharae no kotoba (the great purification).

sen.j: 鶏を集めて鳴かせたことから、伊勢神宮では神宮内に鶏を放し飼いにしている。
sen.e: Ise Jingu Shrine (one of the most important Shinto shrines, where Amaterasu Omikami is enshrined) keeps free-ranged chickens in its site because according to the mythology, the gods gathered chickens, which were made to crow each other.
sen.cmt: 伊勢神宮→（one of the most important Shinto shrines, where Amaterasu Omikami is enshrined) を補足しました
sen.e: Ise Jingu Shrine (one of the most important Shinto shrines, where Amaterasu Omikami is enshrined) keeps free-ranged chickens in its site because according to the mythology, the gods gathered chickens, which were made to crow each other.

Ise Jingu Shrine (one of the most important Shinto shrines, where Amaterasu Omikami is enshrined) keeps free-ranged chickens in its site because according to the mythology, the gods gathered chickens, which were made to crow each other.

sen.j: 鍛冶師のアマツマラについては何をしたかが書かれていないが、本居宣長は矛を作らせるためではないかと推測している。
sen.e: Although the Kojiki describes nothing about what Amatsura, a blacksmith, had done, Norinaga MOTOORI (classical scholar of the Edo period; his aim was to discern the identity of Japanese culture through an intensive study of the ancient classics, especially the Kojiki) assumed that Amatsura might have had a hoko (a long-handled Chinese spear) made.
sen.cmt: 本居宣長→ (classical scholar of the Edo period; his aim was to discern the identity of Japanese culture through an intensive study of the ancient classics, especially the Kojiki) を補足しました。
sen.e: Although the Kojiki describes nothing about what Amatsura, a blacksmith, had done, Norinaga MOTOORI (classical scholar of the Edo period; his aim was to discern the identity of Japanese culture through an intensive study of the ancient classics, especially the Kojiki) assumed that Amatsura might have had a hoko (a long-handled Chinese spear) made.

Although the Kojiki describes nothing about what Amatsura, a blacksmith, had done, Norinaga MOTOORI (classical scholar of the Edo period; his aim was to discern the identity of Japanese culture through an intensive study of the ancient classics, especially the Kojiki) assumed that Amatsura might have had a hoko (a long-handled Chinese spear) made.

sen.j: また、剣を作らせたとする説もあり、そうであればこの説話で三種の神器が全て作られたことになる。
sen.e: Another theory holds that a sword was made; if the theory be correct, all the three imperial regalia (the curved jewels, the sacred mirror, and the sacred sword) would have been made in this mythical story.
sen.cmt: 三種の神器→(the curved jewels, the sacred mirror, and the sacred sword) を補足しました
sen.e: Another theory holds that a sword was made; if the theory be correct, all the three imperial regalia (the curved jewels, the sacred mirror, and the sacred sword) would have been made in this mythical story.

Another theory holds that a sword was made; if the theory be correct, all the three imperial regalia (the curved jewels, the sacred mirror, and the sacred sword) would have been made in this mythical story.

sen.j: なお、古語拾遺においては、アマツマラの代わりに一つ目の鍛冶神天目一箇神が登場している。
sen.e: Additionally, Amenomahitotsu no Kami, a god of smithery, with one eye appeared in the Kogo shui (a historical work complied in 807 by INBE no Hironari, which contains material not found in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, and records of the Inbe family's achievements), instead of Amatsura.
sen.cmt: 古語拾遺→ the Kogo shui (a historical work complied in 807 by INBE no Hironari, which contains material not found in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, and records of the Inbe family's achievements) を補足しました
sen.e: Additionally, Amenomahitotsu no Kami, a god of smithery, with one eye appeared in the Kogo shui (a historical work complied in 807 by INBE no Hironari, which contains material not found in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, and records of the Inbe family's achievements), instead of Amatsura.

Additionally, Amenomahitotsu no Kami, a god of smithery, with one eye appeared in the Kogo shui (a historical work complied in 807 by INBE no Hironari, which contains material not found in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, and records of the Inbe family's achievements), instead of Amatsura.

sen.j: 古事記では、この説話の後に、スサノオとオオゲツヒメによる日本神話における食物起源神話が挿入されている。
sen.e: There was added a food-origin myth of Susano and Ogetsuhime in Japanese mythology to the Ama no Iwato's story in the Kojiki.
There was added a food-origin myth of Susano and Ogetsuhime in Japanese mythology to the Ama no Iwato's story in the Kojiki.
There was added a food-origin myth of Susano and Ogetsuhime in Japanese mythology to the Ama no Iwato's story in the Kojiki.

sen.j: 尚、天目一箇神を祖とする忌部氏（斎部氏）は、オオゲツヒメの話に登場する阿波国を出て東に向かった者とされている。
sen.e: Incidentally, it is believed that the Inbe (忌部) clan (also written in the Chinese character, 斎部 with the identical pronunciation as 忌部) were those who left Awa (阿波) Province, which appeared in the story of Ogetsuhime, for the east.

Incidentally, it is believed that the Inbe (忌部) clan (also written in the Chinese character, 斎部 with the identical pronunciation as 忌部) were those who left Awa (阿波) Province for the east, which appeared in the story of Ogetsuhime.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。また、忌部氏がここで英訳されているようにオオゲツヒメの話に登場する「阿波国」を出て東に向かった者なのか、オオゲツヒメの話に登場する「阿波国を出て東に向かった者」なのか、がはっきりしませんが、後者のように思われたので、その意味での英訳文をしてあります。
sen.e: Incidentally, it is believed that the Inbe (忌部) clan (also written in the Chinese character, 斎部 with the identical pronunciation as 忌部) were those who left Awa (阿波) Province for the east, which appeared in the story of Ogetsuhime.

sen.j: この東端が安房国で安房の地名の由来とされている。
sen.e: The east-end place they reached was Awa Province (another Awa Province written in 安房), which is said to be the origin of Awa (安房)Province.
The east-end place they reached was Awa Province (another Awa Province written in 安房), which is said to be the origin of Awa(安房)Province.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: The east-end place they reached was Awa Province (another Awa Province written in 安房), which is said to be the origin of Awa(安房)Province.

sen.j: 天の岩戸隠れの神話はギリシャ神話に於けるデメテル神の神話とよく似ていると言われている。
sen.e: The myth of heavenly Iwato-gakure is said to be similar to the Demeter myth of Greek mythology.
The myth of heavenly Iwato-gakure is said to be similar to the Demeter myth of Greek mythology.
The myth of heavenly Iwato-gakure is said to be similar to the Demeter myth of Greek mythology.

sen.j: デメテル神の場合、ペルセポネを隠された為、嘆き世の中が真っ暗になってしまう事から来ている。
sen.e: In the myth of Demeter, the abduction of Persephone brought her so deep a grief that she renounced her divine functions as a goddess of vegetation and fruitfulness to lead the world infertile.
sen.cmt: 世の中が真っ暗になる→神としての役目を放棄、不毛の世となる→she renounced her divine function as a goddess of vegetation and fruitfulness to lead the world infertileと意訳しました
sen.e: In the myth of Demeter, the abduction of Persephone brought her so deep a grief that she renounced her divine functions as a goddess of vegetation and fruitfulness to lead the world infertile.
In the myth of Demeter, the abduction of Persephone brought her so deep a grief that she renounced her divine functions as a goddess of vegetation and fruitfulness to lead the world infertile.

tit.j: 天岩戸と呼ばれる場所

sen.j: 天岩戸説話は天上界の出来事であるが、神話を現実的に目に見える形で解釈したいという要求から、「ここが天岩戸である」とする場所や関連する場所が何箇所か存在する。
sen.e: Ama no iwato legend is supposed to have taken place in the heaven, but because of desires to realize that mythology in this world, there exist some caves- 'this is the cave of Ama no iwato'-, or some places associating with Ama no iwato.

Ama no iwato legend is supposed to have taken place in the heaven, but because of desires to realize that mythology in this world, there exist some caves- 'this is the cave of Ama no iwato'-, or some places associating with Ama no iwato.

Ama no iwato legend is supposed to have taken place in the heaven, but because of desires to realize that mythology in this world, there exist some caves- 'this is the cave of Ama no iwato'-, or some places associating with Ama no iwato.

sen.j: 天の岩戸
sen.e: Ama no iwato
Ama no iwato
Ama no iwato

sen.j: 京都府福知山市大江町 (京都府) 皇大神宮（元伊勢内宮）、岩戸神社。
sen.e: One of these caves is enshrined at Iwato-jinja Shrine of Kotai-jingu Shrine (Motoise Naiku Shrine) in Oe-cho (Kyoto Prefecture), Hukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture

sen.j: 社務所に頼まなければ見せてもらうことはできない。
sen.e: To see the Ama no iwato in this shrine, visitors are required to apply to the Amanoiwato-jinja Shrine office for permission.

sen.j: 最寄の駅にも「天岩戸」の名がつけられている（天岩戸駅）。
sen.e: The nearest station to that shrine is named 'Amanoiwato' (Amanoiwato Station)
The nearest station to that shrine is named 'Amanoiwato' (Amanoiwato Station)

sen.j: 沖縄県島尻郡伊平屋村 「クマヤ洞窟」全国に数多ある「天の岩戸伝説」の中でここは最南端地。
sen.e: Kumaya cave' located in Iheya-son, Shimajiri-gun, Okinawa Prefecture is southernmost of the many places related with 'Amaterasu's Heavenly Rock Cave Myth' in Japan.

sen.e: Togakushi-jinja Shrine in Togakushi, Nagano City, Nagano Prefecture holds a tradition that the rock door of Ama no iwato might have fallen there.
